title: Does Lamar Jackson’s 2023 MVP Cement MVP As A ‘Popular QB’ Award?
text:
The Baltimore Ravens had a lot to be proud of in the 2023 NFL season. They went 13-4 finishing with the best record in the NFL while Lamar Jackson took home his second MVP in what was a successful season for the Flock.
On the surface, it looks like a well deserved award. The QB of the best team in the NFL leads his team to another year of soaring heights… but what if you knew 2023’s MVP only led in one single player statistic?


Code
library(tidyverse)
library(ggrepel)
library(gt)
library(patchwork)

qbs <- read_csv("2023QBStats.csv")

everyQB <- read_csv("qbs19752024.csv")

defense <- read_csv("2023defense.csv")

rushing <- read_csv("rushingqbs.csv")

qbstats<- qbs |> 
  filter(Pos == "QB", GS > 14) |> 
  select(Team, Player, TD, Int) |>

  group_by(Player, Team) |>
  summarize(
    Touchdowns = TD,
    Interceptions = Int
  ) |>
  select(Team, Player, Touchdowns, Interceptions) |>
  arrange(desc(Touchdowns)) |> 
  na.omit()


passingyards<- qbs|>
  filter(Pos == "QB", GS > 15)|>
  select(Team, Player, Yds...12) |>
  group_by(Player, Team) |>
  summarize(
    PassingYards = Yds...12,
  ) |>
  select(Team, Player, PassingYards) |>
  arrange(desc(PassingYards)) |> 
  na.omit()

mvps<- everyQB |> filter(grepl("MVP-1", Awards) == TRUE)

mvpstats <-mvps |>
select(Team, Player, Season, TD, Int, PassingYds)|>
filter(Season >2000, PassingYds >3000) |> 
  mutate(PlayerSeason = paste(Player, Season))

lamar<- mvpstats|>
filter(Season == "2023")

peyton <- mvpstats|>
filter(Season == "2013")

lamarfirst <- mvpstats|>
filter(Season == "2019")

mcnair <- mvpstats|>
  filter(Season == "2003", Player== "Steve McNair")

qblabels <- bind_rows(mcnair, lamarfirst, peyton, lamar)

specific <- defense|>
  select(Team, PA, Yds...5)

ravens <- specific |>
  filter(
    Team == "Baltimore Ravens"
  )

niners <- specific |>
  filter(Team == "San Francisco 49ers")

chiefs <- specific |>
  filter(Team == "Kansas City Chiefs")

lions <- specific |>
  filter(Team == "Detroit Lions")

quarterbacks<- rushing|>
  filter(Pos == "QB")|>
  select(Team, Player, TD, Yds) |>
  group_by(Player, Team) |>
  summarize(
    Yards = Yds,
    Touchdowns = TD
  ) |>
  select(Team, Player, Touchdowns, Yards) |>
  arrange(desc(Touchdowns)) |> 
  na.omit()

rushingqbs <- quarterbacks|>
  filter(Yards > 100)

active <- rushingqbs |>
  filter(Touchdowns > 0)

lamaryards <- rushingqbs |>
filter(Player == "Lamar Jackson")

lamartds <- active |>
  filter(Player == "Lamar Jackson")

joshyards <- rushingqbs |>
filter(Player == "Josh Allen")

joshtds <- active |>
  filter(Player == "Josh Allen")

hurtsyards <- rushingqbs |>
filter(Player == "Jalen Hurts")

Hurtstds <- active |>
  filter(Player == "Jalen Hurts")

bar1 <- ggplot() + 
  geom_bar(data=rushingqbs, aes(x=reorder(Player, Yards), weight=Yards),fill ="lightgrey") +  
  geom_bar(data=lamaryards, aes(x=reorder(Player, Yards), weight=Yards), fill="#241773") + 
  geom_bar(data=joshyards, aes(x=reorder(Player, Yards), weight=Yards), fill="#C60C30") + 
  geom_bar(data= hurtsyards, aes(x=reorder(Player, Yards), weight=Yards), fill="#004C54") + 
  coord_flip()+ 
  labs(
    x="", 
    y="2023 Rushing Yards"
    ) + 
  theme_minimal() 

bar2 <- ggplot() + 
  geom_bar(data=active, aes(x=reorder(Player, Touchdowns), weight=Touchdowns), fill= "lightgrey") + 
  geom_bar(data=lamartds, aes(x=reorder(Player, Touchdowns), weight=Touchdowns),fill="#241773")+
  geom_bar(data=joshtds, aes(x=reorder(Player, Touchdowns), weight=Touchdowns),fill="#C60C30")+
  geom_bar(data=Hurtstds, aes(x=reorder(Player, Touchdowns), weight=Touchdowns),fill="#004C54")+
  coord_flip()+ 
  labs(
    x="", 
    y="2023 Rushing TDs"
    ) + 
  theme_minimal() 

bar1 + bar2+ 
  plot_annotation(
    title = "Where Jackson Shines Statistically.",
    subtitle = "How was he as a runner in 2023 compared to other QB's?",
    caption = "Source: Pro Football Reference | By Brandon Roth"
  )& 
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 16, face = "bold"),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 8), 
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size=10), 
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank()
  )









To start off: Lamar Jackson’s strengths. Jackson has been an excellent rusher since he was drafted and 2023 was no different. He led the league in QB rushing yards and the only QB to come close was former Bears QB Justin Fields.
Where this gets interesting is rushing touchdowns. Jackson was blown out of the water in this category. Tying at 5 total with QB’s such as Sam Howell and Desmond Ridder, while Josh Allen and Jalen Hurts tied for 15 rushing touchdowns. While one could argue that it’s due to Buffalo’s stellar red zone run game and Philly’s infamous “Tush Push,” at the end of the day, scoring drives are crucial to winning football games.


Code
qbstats |> 
  arrange(desc(Touchdowns)) |> 
  ungroup() |>
  gt()|>
  cols_label(
    Touchdowns = "Touchdowns",
    Interceptions = "Interceptions"
  )|>
  tab_header(
    title = "The MVP Surely Finished High In Touchdowns... Right?",
    subtitle = "Lamar Jackson finished his 2023 campaign behind 10 other QB's in passing TDs"
  )|> tab_style(
    style = cell_text(color = "black", weight = "bold", align = "left"),
    locations = cells_title("title")
  ) |> tab_style(
    style = cell_text(color = "black", align = "left"),
    locations = cells_title("subtitle")
  )|>
  tab_source_note(
    source_note = md("**By:** Brandon Roth  |  **Source:** Pro Football Reference")
  )|>
  tab_style(
     locations = cells_column_labels(columns = everything()),
     style = list(
       cell_borders(sides = "bottom", weight = px(3)),
       cell_text(weight = "bold", size=12)
     )
   ) |>
  opt_row_striping() |> 
  opt_table_lines("none")|>
  tab_style(
    style = list(
      cell_fill(color = "#241773"),
      cell_text(color = "white")
      ),
    locations = cells_body(
      rows = Player == "Lamar Jackson")
  )

As a Passer, Jackson’s season was middle of the road in terms of touchdowns thrown. Just 24 touchdowns in 16 games started. While 10 other QBs threw more than him.


Code
passingyards |> 
  arrange(desc(PassingYards)) |> 
  ungroup() |>
  gt()|>
  cols_label(
    PassingYards = ""
  )|>
  tab_header(
    title = "Jackson's Passing Yards Were Near Worst In The League As A Starter",
    subtitle = "Below are passing yards of QB's who Started at least 15 games in 2023"
  )|> tab_style(
    style = cell_text(color = "black", weight = "bold", align = "left"),
    locations = cells_title("title")
  ) |> tab_style(
    style = cell_text(color = "black", align = "left"),
    locations = cells_title("subtitle")
  )|>
  tab_source_note(
    source_note = md("**By:** Brandon Roth  |  **Source:** Pro Football Reference")
  )|>
  tab_style(
     locations = cells_column_labels(columns = everything()),
     style = list(
       cell_borders(sides = "bottom", weight = px(3)),

   ) |>

This is where the cracks really start to show. Out of every QB who started at least 15 games, Jackson finished second to last in passing yards thrown, only surpassing Bryce Young of the 2-15 Carolina Panthers.


Code
ggplot() + 
  geom_bar(data=specific, aes(x=reorder(Team, PA), weight=PA), fill = "lightgrey") + 
  geom_bar(data=ravens, aes(x=reorder(Team, PA), weight=PA), fill="#241773") +
  geom_bar(data=niners, aes(x=reorder(Team, PA), weight=PA), fill="#E91E22") +
  geom_bar(data=chiefs, aes(x=reorder(Team, PA), weight=PA), fill="#FFB81C")+
  geom_bar(data=lions, aes(x=reorder(Team, PA), weight=PA), fill="#0076B6")+
  coord_flip() +
  theme_minimal() +
  labs(
    x=" ", 
    y="Total Points Allowed in 2023 Regular Season", 
    title="Baltimore's Defense Was Better Than The Champs.", 
    subtitle="Baltimore's defense only allowed an average of 16.5 ppg. Better than the AFC and NFC champions.", 
    caption="Source: Pro Football Reference | By Brandon Roth"
    ) +
  theme_minimal() + 
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 20, face = "bold"),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 8), 
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size=10), 
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
    plot.title.position = "plot"
    ) 









So if this is the case, if Jackson’s yards and touchdowns are nothing to write home about… How did Baltimore win 13 games and earn themselves a first round bye? It’s simple. The Ravens’ defense was an elite unit who finished first in the league in points allowed.
Only allowing 280 points in 17 games– a league best. This defense statistically was better in that regard than the NFC Champion San Francisco 49ers, and the AFC and Super Bowl Champion Kansas City Chiefs, who both finished right behind Baltimore in points allowed. Interestingly enough, Detroit, who lost to the 49ers in the NFC Championship, had a significantly worse defense statistically.


Code
ggplot() + 
  geom_point(data=mvpstats, aes(x=PassingYds, y=TD), color= "grey") +
  geom_point(
    data=lamar, 
    aes(x=PassingYds, y=TD), 
     color="#241773", 
    size=2) +
  geom_vline(xintercept = 4364.208) + 
  geom_hline(yintercept = 37.20833, label= "Average MVP Stats") +
  geom_point(
    data=peyton, 
    aes(x=PassingYds, y=TD),
    color="#FB4F14") +
  geom_point(
    data=mcnair, 
    aes(x=PassingYds, y=TD),
    color="#4B92DB")+
  geom_point(
    data=lamarfirst, 
    aes(x=PassingYds, y=TD),
    color="#9E7C0C")+
  geom_text_repel(
    data=qblabels, 
    aes(x=PassingYds, y=TD, label= PlayerSeason)) +
  labs(
    x="Passing Yards", 
    y="Passing Touchdowns", 
    title="Jackson Was Underwhelming Compared To His Peers.", 
    subtitle="it was the second lowest passer statistics compared to the other QB's who have won MVP since 2000", 
    caption="Source: Pro Football Reference | By Brandon Roth"
    ) +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 17, face = "bold"),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 12), 
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size=10), 
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
    plot.title.position = "plot"
    ) 









The average MVP passing season is around 37 touchdowns and 4300 yards. While examining the other quarterbacks who have won MVP since 2000, Lamar Jackson had the second worst MVP passing season, only passing 2003 Steve McNair, who shared the award with Colts QB Peyton Manning.
So… Why did Jackson win this award? Does being the QB of the team with the best record automatically get you the award?
Former MVP’s statistically were better than Jackson was. So that argument was taken with a grain of salt, but with situations like this, it’s easy to understand the frustration of fans. If Cooper Kupp, who won the triple crown in 2021 and Tyreek Hill, who nearly broke 2,000 yards in the 2023 season, and 2024 Saquon Barkley who rushed for over 2,000 yards all STILL lose… it’s easy to understand how one can come to that conclusion.
Even with the 2024 NFL season. The Kansas City Chiefs were 15-2 and Patrick Mahomes was in the MVP conversation despite being middle of the road in most statistics. It seemed like it would be more of the same old noise…
However, last season the status quo changed. Voters couldn’t make Mahomes winning it make sense because he was not near the best QB, while ironically Lamar Jackson boasted some of the best stats in the NFL and Saquon Barkley nearly broke the single season rushing record while leading the Eagles to a 14-3 record– All lost to Buffalo Bills QB Josh Allen, who was one of the league’s best QBs on the second best team in the AFC.
It seems times are changing in the NFL as this is the first season since 2020 that the award has gone to somebody who is not on the best team, but in the last 10 seasons (2015-2024) 70% of MVPs have, all were quarterbacks.

title: The Bizzare Suffering Of Cleveland Browns Quarterbacks
text:
The Cleveland Browns are one of the NFL’s most storied franchises. Boasting four early NFL Championships and overseeing legendary careers by Hall of Famers such as Jim Brown, Otto Graham, and Ozzy Newsome. However, after the team moved to Baltimore in 1995, and then revived in 1999, it has been nothing but an uphill battle. Since their return, the Browns have been the NFL’s punching bag with only a few fleeting seasons where fans could feel pride for the orange and brown.


Code
library(tidyverse)
library(gt)
library(ggalt)
library(ggrepel)
library(ggbeeswarm)
browns <- read_csv("BrownsQbs.csv")
brownshistory<- read_csv("brownshistory.csv")
everyQB<- read_csv("qbs19752024.csv")

return <- browns|>
  filter(From > 1998)

brownstable <- return |>
  filter(Pos == "QB", G > 7) |> 
  select(Player, From, To, G, QBrec) |>
  group_by(Player) |>
  summarize(
    From = From,
    To = To,
    G = G,
    QBrec = QBrec
  ) |>
  select(Player, From, To, G, QBrec) |>
  arrange(desc(G)) |> 
  na.omit()

bh <- brownshistory |>
  mutate(Tm = gsub("Cleveland Browns*", "Cleveland Browns", Tm, fixed = TRUE))
bmp <- bh |>
  filter(Year == "2020")
dkzero <- bh |>
  filter(Year == "2017")
modern <- everyQB |>
  filter(Season > 1998, PassingYds >500)
modernbrowns <- modern |>
  filter(Team == "CLE")
mvps<- everyQB |> filter(grepl("MVP-1", Awards) == TRUE & Season > 1998) 
Bucsbaker <- everyQB |>
  filter(Player== "Baker Mayfield", Season== "2024")
Bakermayfield <- modernbrowns |>
  filter(Season == "2020", Player == "Baker Mayfield")
derekanderson <- modernbrowns |>
  filter(Season == "2007", Player== "Derek Anderson")




Code
ggplot() + 
  geom_line(data=bh, aes(x= Year, y=W, group=Tm), color="grey") +
  geom_point(data=bh, aes(x=Year, y=W, group=Tm), color="grey") +
  geom_line(data=bmp, aes(x= Year, y=W, group=Tm), color="orange") +
  geom_point(data=bmp, aes(x=Year, y=W, group=Tm), color="orange") +
  geom_line(data=dkzero, aes(x= Year, y=W, group=Tm), color="brown") +
  geom_point(data=dkzero, aes(x=Year, y=W, group=Tm), color="brown") +
  geom_text(data=bh |> filter(Year == max(Year)), aes(x=Year + .2, y=W+.1, group=Tm, label="")) + 
  geom_text(data=bmp |> filter(Year == min(Year)), aes(x=Year - .2, y= W, group=Tm, label="Baker Mayfield")) + 
    annotate("rect", fill = "blue", alpha = 0.1, 
        xmin = 2020, xmax = 2023,
        ymin = 7, ymax = 11) +
  geom_text(aes(x=2021.5, y=9, label="Consecutive 7+ Win Seasons"), size=3) +
  geom_text(data=dkzero |> filter(Year == max(Year)), aes(x=Year + .2, y=W , group=Tm, label="Deshone Kizer")) + 
  
 labs(
    x="Seasons Since 1999", 
    y="Wins", 
    title="The Never Ending Rollercoaster Of The Browns' Seasons", 
    subtitle="The Cleveland Browns have four winning seasons in 25 years", 
    caption="Source: Pro Football Reference | By Brandon Roth"
    ) +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 17, face = "bold"),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 12), 
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size=10), 
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
    plot.title.position = "plot"
    ) 









Cleveland’s seasons drawn out look more like a heart monitor. There has been a lack of stability since the moment the Browns returned. The miserable seasons led to the flatline: 2017, a shocking 0-16 season, only the second in NFL history (2008 Detroit.) This led to Cleveland Drafting Baker Mayfield first overall from Oklahoma, who would lead them to their best season in 2020, an 11-5 record and their first playoff win since 1995.
The Browns have also had the benefit of having the same head coach, Kevin Stefanski, since 2020, before that it was a coaching carousel.
After a disappointing 2021 season (7-10,) the Browns gambled their future on Texans quarterback Deshaun Watson, who since joining Cleveland never recaptured the magic he had in his Houston days,and brought with him an overwhelming amount of off-the-field controversy. Going into year four with the Browns, he has only started 19 games, with a 9-10 record. The 2023 success Cleveland saw was not due to Watson’s play, four quarterbacks started that season, the most memerable being Joe Flacco’s surprising 4-1 run to lead the Browns to the playoffs.
In 2024, the team fell off a cliff back into the basement of the NFL, their worst season since 2017.

  arrange(desc(G)) |> 
  ungroup() |>
  gt()|>
  cols_label(
    Player = "Player",

    QBrec = "Starter Record"
  )|>

Baker Mayfield and Tim Couch had the longest tenures in Cleveland but neither lasted longer than 5 years. Compared to the other 38 that played, those two look like Hall of Famers and even they did not end their tenures with winning seasons. Only three have done that: Joe Flacco (4-1) , Case Keenum (2-0), and Brian Hoyer (10-6). None started a full season. With all of these quarterbacks playing left and right, the rest of the team never truly found stability behind them.
The 2024 season marked 25 years since the Browns had returned to the NFL. After a miserable 4-13 season, the Browns seem to be in rebuild mode once again. Drafting two QBs in the 2025 draft: Dillon Gabriel and Sheduer Sanders. Time will tell how their careers will go… but how did their peers fair in their time in Cleveland?


Code
ggplot() + 
  geom_beeswarm(data=modern, aes(x=TD, y=Season), color="grey") +
  geom_beeswarm(data=mvps, 
    aes(x=TD, y=Season), color="gold") +
  geom_beeswarm(data=modernbrowns, 
    aes(x=TD, y=Season), color="#311D00") +
  geom_beeswarm(data=Bakermayfield, 
    aes(x=TD, y=Season), color="#FF3C00") +
  geom_beeswarm(data=derekanderson, 
    aes(x=TD, y=Season), color="black") +
  geom_beeswarm(data=Bucsbaker, 
    aes(x=TD, y=Season), color="#D50A0A") +
  geom_text_repel(
    data=Bakermayfield, 
    aes(x=TD, y=Season, label=Player)) +
geom_text_repel(
    data=derekanderson, 
    aes(x=TD, y=Season, label=Player)) +
  geom_text_repel(
    data=Bucsbaker, 
    aes(x=TD, y=Season, label=Player)) +
 labs(
    x="Passing Touchdowns", 
    y="", 
    title="Browns QBs Make Up Some Of The Worst Passers In The NFL", 
    subtitle="Baker Mayfield had the best tenure, but at his best was above average", 
    caption="Source: Pro Football Reference | By Brandon Roth"
    ) +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 17, face = "bold"),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 12), 
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size=10), 
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
    plot.title.position = "plot"
    ) 









Quarterbacks who have had the unfortunate circumstance of playing in Cleveland in their careers have been well below average passers. compared to other players and the MVPs (gold) only 2 quarterbacks have seen a full season of success. title: The Bizarre Suffering Of Cleveland Browns Quarterbacks
text:
The Cleveland Browns are one of the NFL’s most storied franchises. Boasting four early NFL Championships and overseeing legendary careers by Hall of Famers such as Jim Brown, Otto Graham, and Ozzie Newsome. However, after the team moved to Baltimore in 1995, and then revived in 1999, it has been nothing but an uphill battle. Since their return, the Browns have been the NFL’s punching bag with only a few fleeting seasons where fans could feel pride for the orange and brown.


Code
library(tidyverse)
library(gt)
library(ggalt)
library(ggrepel)
library(ggbeeswarm)
browns <- read_csv("BrownsQbs.csv")
brownshistory<- read_csv("brownshistory.csv")
everyQB<- read_csv("qbs19752024.csv")

return <- browns|>
  filter(From > 1998)

brownstable <- return |>
  filter(Pos == "QB", G > 7) |> 
  select(Player, From, To, G, QBrec) |>
  group_by(Player) |>
  summarize(
    From = From,
    To = To,
    G = G,
    QBrec = QBrec
  ) |>
  select(Player, From, To, G, QBrec) |>
  arrange(desc(G)) |> 
  na.omit()

bh <- brownshistory |>
  mutate(Tm = gsub("Cleveland Browns*", "Cleveland Browns", Tm, fixed = TRUE))
bmp <- bh |>
  filter(Year == "2020")
dkzero <- bh |>
  filter(Year == "2017")
modern <- everyQB |>
  filter(Season > 1998, PassingYds >500)
modernbrowns <- modern |>
  filter(Team == "CLE")
mvps<- everyQB |> filter(grepl("MVP-1", Awards) == TRUE & Season > 1998) 
Bucsbaker <- everyQB |>
  filter(Player== "Baker Mayfield", Season== "2024")
Bakermayfield <- modernbrowns |>
  filter(Season == "2020", Player == "Baker Mayfield")
derekanderson <- modernbrowns |>
  filter(Season == "2007", Player== "Derek Anderson")




Code
ggplot() + 
  geom_line(data=bh, aes(x= Year, y=W, group=Tm), color="grey") +
  geom_point(data=bh, aes(x=Year, y=W, group=Tm), color="grey") +
  geom_line(data=bmp, aes(x= Year, y=W, group=Tm), color="orange") +
  geom_point(data=bmp, aes(x=Year, y=W, group=Tm), color="orange") +
  geom_line(data=dkzero, aes(x= Year, y=W, group=Tm), color="brown") +
  geom_point(data=dkzero, aes(x=Year, y=W, group=Tm), color="brown") +
  geom_text(data=bh |> filter(Year == max(Year)), aes(x=Year + .2, y=W+.1, group=Tm, label="")) + 
  geom_text(data=bmp |> filter(Year == min(Year)), aes(x=Year - .2, y= W, group=Tm, label="Baker Mayfield")) + 
    annotate("rect", fill = "blue", alpha = 0.1, 
        xmin = 2020, xmax = 2023,
        ymin = 7, ymax = 11) +
  geom_text(aes(x=2021.5, y=9, label="Consecutive 7+ Win Seasons"), size=3) +
  geom_text(data=dkzero |> filter(Year == max(Year)), aes(x=Year + .2, y=W , group=Tm, label="Deshone Kizer")) + 
  
 labs(
    x="Seasons Since 1999", 
    y="Wins", 
    title="The Never Ending Rollercoaster Of The Browns' Seasons", 
    subtitle="The Cleveland Browns have four winning seasons in 25 years", 
    caption="Source: Pro Football Reference | By Brandon Roth"
    ) +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 17, face = "bold"),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 12), 
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size=10), 
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
    plot.title.position = "plot"
    ) 









Cleveland’s seasons drawn out look more like a heart monitor. There has been a lack of stability since the moment the Browns returned. The miserable seasons led to the flatline: 2017, a shocking 0-16 season, only the second in NFL history (2008 Detroit.) This led to Cleveland Drafting Baker Mayfield first overall from Oklahoma, who would lead them to their best season in 2020, an 11-5 record and their first playoff win since 1995.
The Browns have also had the benefit of having the same head coach, Kevin Stefanski, since 2020, before that it was a coaching carousel.
After a disappointing 2021 season (7-10,) the Browns gambled their future on Texans quarterback Deshaun Watson, who since joining Cleveland never recaptured the magic he had in his Houston days,and brought with him an overwhelming amount of off-the-field controversy. Going into year four with the Browns, he has only started 19 games, with a 9-10 record. The 2023 success Cleveland saw was not due to Watson’s play, four quarterbacks started that season, the most memerable being Joe Flacco’s surprising 4-1 run to lead the Browns to the playoffs.
In 2024, the team fell off a cliff back into the basement of the NFL, their worst season since 2017.


Code
brownstable |> 
  arrange(desc(G)) |> 
  ungroup() |>
  gt()|>
  cols_label(
    Player = "Player",
    From = "From",
    To = "To",
    G = "Games",
    QBrec = "Starter Record"
  )|>
  tab_header(
    title = "Only One Browns QBs Has Lasted Five Seasons Since 1999",
    subtitle = "The factory of sadness churns out new QBs left and right"
  )|> tab_style(
    style = cell_text(color = "black", weight = "bold", align = "left"),
    locations = cells_title("title")
  ) |> tab_style(

  )|>

  )|>

      ),

  )|>

Baker Mayfield and Tim Couch had the longest tenures in Cleveland but neither lasted longer than 5 years. Compared to the other 38 that played, those two look like Hall of Famers and even they did not end their tenures with winning seasons. Only three have done that: Joe Flacco (4-1) , Case Keenum (2-0), and Brian Hoyer (10-6). None started a full season. With all of these quarterbacks playing left and right, the rest of the team never truly found stability behind them.
The 2024 season marked 25 years since the Browns had returned to the NFL. After a miserable 4-13 season, the Browns seem to be in rebuild mode once again. Drafting two QBs in the 2025 draft: Dillon Gabriel and Sheduer Sanders. Time will tell how their careers will go… but how did their peers fair in their time in Cleveland?
